title: Dashboard
text:
Interactive Dashboard: Explore the Data Yourself
Below is the full Power BI dashboard that powers all the visualizations and analysis presented throughout this project. Use the interactive filters to drill down into specific airlines, dates, states, and time periods to uncover additional patterns and insights beyond what’s been highlighted here. Whether you’re interested in a particular carrier’s performance, regional weather impacts, or daily operational trends, the dashboard allows you to explore the data from multiple angles and discover your own data-driven stories within January 2025’s flight operations.
Press on the “Fullscreen” button in the bottom right and then the “Fit to Page” button in the bottom right to fit with your computer or monitor size.

title: Airline Delays
text:
We will next look at delays across different airlines along with their different reasons and drawing conclusions from these visuals.
Below is a page from the dashboard with overall cancellation and delay metrics at the top. The graph in the middle left represents delay counts different delay length categories. The table in the middle right shows average delay minutes by days of the week. The barchart on the bottom shows the average delay minutes by each airline.



Delays page


Nearly one in three flights (32.8%) experienced delays in January 2025, with 177,110 delayed departures out of 539,750 total flights. The average delay of 14.09 minutes might seem modest, but multiplied across thousands of daily flights, this translates to countless missed connections, disrupted travel plans, and significant economic impact.
Interestingly, when flights do depart early, which represents a positive passenger experience, they leave an average of just 6 minutes ahead of schedule, suggesting airlines maintain relatively tight scheduling with limited buffer time.
The “Delay Counts per Category” reveals that while 362,000 flights departed on time, delays show a clear pattern:

84,690 flights experienced 1-15 minute delays (the largest delay category)
Sharp drop-off to 31,832 flights delayed 16-30 minutes
28,119 flights faced 31-60 minute delays
31,622 flights (5.8% of all flights) were delayed over one hour

Delays exceeding 30-60 minutes typically cascade into missed connections and significant passenger disruption. The concentration in the 1-15 minute category suggests that operational improvements in ground handling and boarding could substantially improve system-wide performance.
When Delays Peak
Mondays are worst with 17.19 minutes average delay—likely due to weekend weather carryover and business travel rush Wednesdays show best performance at just 9.68 minutes Weekends see elevated delays (Saturday: 15.92, Sunday: 17.13 minutes)
High-Delay Airlines:

Allegiant Air (21.69 minutes) and PSA Airlines (22.14 minutes) lead in delays
PSA’s dual challenge: High cancellations AND longest delays suggest severe operational issues

Top Performers:

Republic Airline (7.69 minutes)—less than half the industry average
Alaska (9.93 minutes) and Southwest (9.93 minutes) demonstrate operational excellence with delays below 10 minutes

The Southwest Paradox: Cancel vs. Delay Strategy Southwest’s combination of high cancellations but low delays (9.93 minutes) reveals a possible strategic operational philosophy: cancel proactively rather than delay extensively. This contrasts with PSA and Allegiant, which appear to delay flights rather than cancel, potentially leaving passengers waiting for extended periods—arguably a worse experience than a clear cancellation with rebooking options. Key Insights
The 1-15 minute delay concentration indicates ground operation improvements could significantly boost on-time performance Day-of-week patterns suggest predictable capacity constraints that passengers and airlines can plan around.
PSA Airlines’ dual challenges with both high delays and cancellations may warrant an operational review to identify systemic issues affecting performance. However, it’s worth noting that regional weather patterns likely play a significant role in these metrics, as many airlines operate heavily in specific geographic areas—winter storms in the Northeast and Midwest can disproportionately impact carriers with concentrated hub operations. This geographic concentration means that localized weather events can dramatically skew an airline’s national performance statistics. For example, PSA typically operates up and down the east coast, where snowstorms consistently hit every winter.

title: Geographic Trends
text:
We will next examine delays and cancellations across states to track how major weather events impacted U.S. air travel throughout January 2025.
Below is a map of the U.S. offering three analytical views: average delay in minutes by state, total cancellation counts by state, and cancellation percentage by state. These views reveal distinct geographic patterns in flight disruptions.
By analyzing three significant winter storms that struck in January 2025, we can trace the movement and cascading effects of these weather systems across the country through state-level cancellation percentages.
Use the interactive Dashboard tab to explore these patterns in detail—filter by specific dates, airlines, and states to see how individual storms and operational factors shaped flight disruptions throughout the month.

title: Geographic Trends
text:
1. January 5–6, 2025 United States blizzard
This winter storm tracked from the Midwest to the East Coast over January 5-6, 2025. The maps below display states that experienced cancellation rates exceeding 30% during this period, illustrating the storm’s impact on air travel as it moved across the country.







Cancellations on Jan 5
Cancellations on Jan 6








• Kansas: 92.6%  • Missouri: 79.3%  • Kentucky: 41.8%
• West Virginia: 100%  • Virginia: 68.75%  • Maryland: 57.87%  • Kentucky: 55.6%  • Missouri: 53.1%  • Kansas: 39.7%



Cancellations on Jan 5-6 

Kansas — 67.1%
Missouri — 66.8%
West Virginia — 63.6%
Kentucky — 48.7%
Virginia — 37.5%
Maryland — 30.3%

The geographic impact of the January 5-6, 2025 blizzard is strikingly evident in the cancellation data, with states in the storm’s direct path experiencing catastrophic disruption to air travel. Kansas and Missouri bore the brunt of the storm, with cancellation rates exceeding 66% across the two-day period, while the storm’s eastward progression left West Virginia, Kentucky, Virginia, and Maryland with cancellation rates ranging from 30% to 64%.

title: Geographic Trends
text:
2. January 9–10, 2025 United States winter storm
This winter storm tracked from the Mid-South to the South-East over January 9-10, 2025. The maps below display states that experienced cancellation rates exceeding 30% during this period, illustrating the storm’s impact on air travel as it moved across the country.







Cancellations on Jan 9
Cancellations on Jan 10








• Texas — 53.5%  • Arkansas — 36.6%  • Kansas — 33.3%
• Georgia — 80.7%  • Arkansas — 65.7%  • Alabama — 63.4%  • Tennessee — 57.9%  • North Carolina — 45.9%  • Mississippi — 36.7%



Cancellations on Jan 9-10 

Arkansas — 50.7%
Alabama — 44.4%
Georgia — 42.0%
Texas — 37.6%
Tennessee — 32.9%
Mississippi — 32.8%

The January 9-10, 2025 winter storm’s path through the Mid-South and Southeast reveals a similar pattern of severe disruption, with the storm’s impact intensifying as it moved eastward. Georgia experienced the most severe single-day impact with an 80.7% cancellation rate on January 10, while Arkansas faced sustained disruption across both days with a combined 50.7% cancellation rate. The storm’s unusual track through typically warmer southern states—where airports are less equipped for winter weather operations—contributed to the high cancellation rates, with major hubs in Atlanta, Charlotte, and other southeastern cities effectively paralyzed during the storm’s peak.

title: Geographic Trends
text:
3. January 20-22, 2025 Gulf Coast blizzard
This winter storm tracked from the Gulf Coast of the U.S. over January 21-22, 2025. The maps below display states that experienced cancellation rates exceeding 30% during this period, illustrating the storm’s impact on air travel as it moved across the country.







Cancellations on Jan 21
Cancellations on Jan 22








• Louisiana — 93.0%  • Mississippi — 73.1%  • Texas — 37.76%  • West Virginia — 33.3%
• Louisiana — 91.7%  • South Carolina — 65.6%  • Mississippi — 60.7%  • West Virginia — 30.0%



Cancellations on Jan 21-22 

Louisiana - 92.3%
Mississippi - 66.7%
South Carolina - 41.9%
West Virginia - 31.6%

The January 21-22, 2025 Gulf Coast blizzard delivered the most concentrated and severe disruption of the month, with Louisiana experiencing a near-total aviation shutdown at 92.3% cancellations across the two-day period. This rare winter weather event in the Deep South caught the region particularly unprepared, as Gulf Coast airports rarely encounter snow and ice conditions—Louisiana and Mississippi’s sustained cancellation rates above 60% reflect both the severity of the storm and the lack of winter weather infrastructure in these typically mild climates. The storm’s impact on South Carolina (41.9%) demonstrates how the system continued to disrupt air travel as it tracked along the Atlantic coast, compounding the challenges faced by airlines already dealing with displaced crews and aircraft from earlier January storms.

title: Geographic Trends
text:
Conclusion
January 2025’s three major winter storms demonstrate how concentrated weather events can effectively paralyze regional air travel, with cancellation rates exceeding 90% in the hardest-hit states. The compounding effects of successive storms—particularly for airlines with displaced crews and aircraft—underscore the vulnerability of the national aviation network to severe weather. Return to the Dashboard to explore additional patterns in delay reasons, airline-specific performance, and temporal trends throughout the month.

title: Airline Cancellations
text:
We will begin by looking at overall cancellations across different airlines along with their different reasons and drawing conclusions from these visuals.
Below is an with overall cancelattions and delay metrics at the top. The graph in the middle left represents cancellations by grouping of reason. The table in the middle right shows cancellations by days of the week. The barchart on the bottom shows cancellation counts for each airline clustered by cancellation reason.



Cancellations page


We can see the total amount of flights in the month of January 2025 was nearly 540K flights with about 16.3K cancellations. This means about 3% of flights were cancelled in January 2025.
Most of the cancellations occured on Thursday and Friday. Also we see that the top cancellers for the month of January were American, PSA, Delta, and Southwest accounting for more than 60% of the cancellations, which may suggest that the hubs of those airports may have been hit with inclement weather over the month.
Of course, most of the cancellations in the month were due to weather, however if we take a look at the bar chart showing the grouping of cancallation reason with airlines, we can see both delta and PSA had a large spike in Carrier cancellation reasons, suggesting internal issues with both Delta and PSA over the month of January. This can point to possible staffing issues or issues with the aircraft. An issue with the aircraft could have arised from the inclement weather over the course of January, as we will explore in the map visual tab.

title: Day-by-Day Behavior
text:
The timeline visualization below provides a comprehensive day-by-day view of flight disruptions throughout January 2025, revealing how the three major winter storms created dramatic spikes in both cancellations and delays against an otherwise stable operational baseline.

The day-over-day visualization reveals the dramatic volatility in U.S. air travel throughout January 2025, with three distinct spikes in cancellations that directly correspond to the major winter storms analyzed earlier. The correlation between total minutes delayed (dark blue) and flights cancelled (light blue) tells an operational story: when weather conditions deteriorate severely, airlines shift from delaying flights to outright cancellations, as seen in the towering peaks on January 6th, 10th, and 21st-22nd.
The January 5-6 blizzard created the first major disruption, with cancellations surging to nearly 2,000 flights on January 6th as the storm moved from the Midwest to the East Coast. Notably, total delay minutes peaked slightly earlier on January 5th at around 3,500 minutes, suggesting airlines initially attempted to operate through deteriorating conditions before making the decision to cancel more aggressively the following day. This pattern of delay spikes preceding cancellation spikes reflects the difficult real-time decisions airlines must make as weather conditions evolve.
The most severe disruption occurred during the January 9-10 storm, where cancellations exploded to nearly 3,000 flights on January 10th, the highest single-day cancellation count of the month. This peak aligns with the 80.7% cancellation rate observed in Georgia, home to the nation’s busiest airport in Atlanta. The Gulf Coast blizzard on January 21-22 produced a more sustained disruption pattern, with elevated cancellations across both days (approximately 1,500-1,700 flights) rather than a single dramatic spike, reflecting Louisiana and Mississippi’s complete shutdown over the extended period. Between these major events, the system demonstrates strong resilience, quickly returning to baseline levels of 100-200 daily cancellations and minimal delays, though each successive storm likely compounded operational challenges through crew and aircraft displacement.

title: Mini-Project-Website
text:
Cancellation Performance Across Airlines
We begin by examining which airlines had the highest cancellation counts and explore the underlying causes recorded in the dataset. These are then connected to relevant real-world events—such as major weather systems—to contextualize the spikes in airline disruptions.
Delay Performance Across Airlines
Next, we analyze average delay times from several perspectives:

Overall delay performance by airline
Comparisons between arrival and departure delays
How severe delays cluster across carriers

This section highlights which airlines struggled most and whether the causes appear systemic, weather-related, or operational.
Geographic Trends: Cancellations and Delays by State
Using a U.S. map visualization, we explore how cancellations and delays varied geographically throughout January. This portion examines:

Which states experienced the most flight cancellations
How the percentage of flights cancelled differs from the raw totals
The extent to which January weather patterns correlate with disruption hotspots

Time Trends: Day-by-Day Behavior
Finally, we view cancellations and delays over the entire month, identifying:

Days with high delays but low cancellations
Days with high cancellations but minimal delay buildup
Days where both metrics spiked simultaneously

This helps reveal whether disruptions were isolated events or part of broader patterns.
Interactive Dashboard
All visualizations used in the report come from a custom Power BI dashboard embedded at the end of the site. This dashboard includes multiple pages that allow for interactive exploration beyond the static images shown in the narrative.
